channel.title: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!
channel.description:
I think I finally have torrent support for java wrapped up, hopefully. Can you all download this jar:
https://www.moparisthebest.com/downloads/ResourceGrabber.jar
And run it, this is the usage, also obtained by running without any arguments: [code]java -jar ResourceGrabber.jar Usage: ResourceGrabber [[TORRENT|MAGNETURL|URL] SAVE_PATH EXTRACT CRC] TORRENT is a path to a .torrent file MAGNETURL is a magnet link URL is a url to a torrent file, or any file over HTTP SAVE_PATH is the absolute path to save the torrent and .resume file to EXTRACT is true if you wish to extract the downloaded file CRC if not 0 will only download the file if the CRC does not match, it will checksum every file in the save_path recursively.
You can specify as many downloads on the command line as you wish.[/code]
An example that will download the free and legal Ubuntu 11.04 iso via bittorrent is this: [code]java -jar ResourceGrabber.jar "magnet:?xt=urn:btih:a38d02c287893842a32825aa866e00828a318f07&dn=Ubuntu+11.04+%28Final%29&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.openbittorrent.com%3A80&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.publicbt.com%3A80&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.ccc.de%3A80" "/tmp" false 0[/code] Don't forget the quotes due to the funky characters in there.
Also try multiple downloads at the same time, you can specify as many as you want!
You can download anything supported by Java's URLConnection class (as far as I know, HTTP and HTTPS, also possibly FTP), and any torrent via file, magnet url, and HTTP url to the torrent itself. It will pop up a nice little GUI showing you the progress, and also tell you some key points via command line. This will download my platform-specific java_client to your computer, but will only run it if the CRC matches.
It will NOT download or extract any files with the following extensions, for safety: ".exe", ".bat", ".cmd", ".com", ".sh", ".bash"
Please post logs if you have any problems, and as always post hints/suggestions. All of this code will be released free and open source under the GNU/GPL, probably at github. It is written modulary enough where you can write any front-end you want, this one just happens to be Swing.
If any of you are actually worried, or just curious, I attached the full java source, as well as the C++ source code to the binary, and my build scripts. When I officially release it, it will probably be at github: https://www.moparisthebest.com/downloads/ResourceGrabber.src.7z

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Could you guys please test this once more? I believe I have the windows problem fixed and it should download on that operating system now (I’ve tested XP), I shouldn’t have done anything to break Linux/OSX support, but if you wouldn’t mind testing the new one I’d appreciate that as well.

Read full topic
item.source: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!

item.title: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Oh yea, I use Transmission personally, it uses libtransmission (which I also considered for this, but it’s not cross-platform). Can you try setting transmission to only make encrypted connections and see if it works then (by default it prefers encryption, but will make standard connections too)? That’s the only difference I can think of.

It works now, even though I did nothing differently. I think it had something to do with the tracker being down.

Though, it’s extremely slow compared to Transmission (with require encryption), even on the same torrent… It’s by at least a factor of 100, and I saw over a factor of 1000 once I actually started maxing out my connection. Though, it might be how you’re calculating the download speed.

Read full topic

item.title: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:32, topic:403921”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=500979.msg3671300#msg3671300 date=1310942642]

@CodeForFame, Davidi2, Mitko, if the state is set to ‘dl metadata’ then the native client has started up correctly, and it’s trying to get the metadata from the DHT swarm, (sometimes it takes a bit of time), if it can’t do that, then probably a firewall is to blame.

It’s not, I just tried it with no ports blocked at all, and all traffic allowed. I also let it sit for over 10 minutes. I also tried using the ‘default’ BitTtorrent client that comes installed on Ubuntu, and it worked just fine (just like on my other PC).
[/quote]

What is the ‘default’ client? Do you know what library it uses? I use libtorrent-rasterbar.[/quote]
It’s called ‘Transmission’.

Here is the site:
http://www.transmissionbt.com/
IRC:
irc.freenode.net/transmission

Read full topic

It’s not, I just tried it with no ports blocked at all, and all traffic allowed. I also let it sit for over 10 minutes. I also tried using the ‘default’ BitTtorrent client that comes installed on Ubuntu, and it worked just fine (just like on my other PC).[/quote]

What is the ‘default’ client? Do you know what library it uses? I use libtorrent-rasterbar.

item.title: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:22, topic:403921”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=500979.msg3666459#msg3666459 date=1310656915]
It doesn’t start at all (I waited like 10 minutes, and it starts in less than 30 seconds for other torrent programs).

I have a rather complex network setup, and have pretty strict firewall settings (hardware and software), but I didn’t see any events in any of the logs… Anyway, it has the ‘standard’ ports open, and no other torrent programs have an issue, nor do other applications that use a P2P protocol (once I actually allow them, if they’re not already allowed).
[/quote]

I always use a random port, and only operate with encryption (don’t connect to non-encrypted clients at all), I also make a request to forward the port via UPnP and NAT-PMP, would that make a difference?[/quote]
I’m not entirely sure… I’ll test it later on another box, then if it doesn’t work, just allow everything for a bit.

Read full topic
item.source: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!

item.title: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

So I’m testing it on my Ubuntu 10.04 now.

Note this is actually like my third our fourth day using torrents in general, I have no clue what I’m doing in regards to torrents, but I figured I’d try to help anyway.

I tried using a magnet link from TPB:

java -jar '/home/david/Downloads/ResourceGrabber.jar' 'magnet:?xt=urn:btih:1a5bc9ca213a79e9427b4f61f0b1fa05751dbf7f&dn=BIRDMAN_OF_THE_KARAKORAM.m4v&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.openbittorrent.com%3A80&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.publicbt.com%3A80&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.ccc.de%3A80' . false 0 Starting download 1, url: 'magnet:?xt=urn:btih:1a5bc9ca213a79e9427b4f61f0b1fa05751dbf7f&dn=BIRDMAN_OF_THE_KARAKORAM.m4v&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.openbittorrent.com%3A80&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.publicbt.com%3A80&tr=udp%3A%2F%2Ftracker.ccc.de%3A80' savePath: '.' extract: 'false' crc: '0' Checksum so far: 0 Checking filename: /home/david/.moparscape/bin/java_client.linux.x86 Started download 1 Started all downloads, now waiting until they all finish! However it’s not downloading at all.

I downloaded the torrent file of the same thing…

java -jar '/home/david/Downloads/ResourceGrabber.jar' '/home/david/Downloads/BIRDMAN_OF_THE_KARAKORAM.m4v.6542819.TPB.torrent' /home/david/Downloads false 0 Starting download 1, url: '/home/david/Downloads/BIRDMAN_OF_THE_KARAKORAM.m4v.6542819.TPB.torrent' savePath: '/home/david/Downloads' extract: 'false' crc: '0' Checksum so far: 0 Checking filename: /home/david/.moparscape/bin/java_client.linux.x86 Started download 1 Started all downloads, now waiting until they all finish!Same thing

Again I have no clue what I’m doing, if I used some improper arguments tell me so I can fix it XD

EDIT - It looks like it was just a path error, I wasn’t cd’ing to the right place and finding the right folder

java -jar ResourceGrabber.jar BIRDMAN_OF_THE_KARAKORAM.m4v.6542819.TPB.torrent '/TEST' false 0 Starting download 1, url: 'BIRDMAN_OF_THE_KARAKORAM.m4v.6542819.TPB.torrent' savePath: '/TEST' extract: 'false' crc: '0' Checksum so far: 0 Checking filename: /home/david/.moparscape/bin/java_client.linux.x86 java_client exit code: 1 Started download 1 Started all downloads, now waiting until they all finish! Download 1 failed, here is the exception: java.io.IOException: stream is over? so soon? process must have ended... at org.moparscape.res.impl.BTDownloader.readNextTag(BTDownloader.java:135) at org.moparscape.res.impl.BTDownloader.readNextTag(BTDownloader.java:122) at org.moparscape.res.impl.BTDownloader.download(BTDownloader.java:243) at org.moparscape.res.ResourceGrabber.download(ResourceGrabber.java:218) at org.moparscape.res.ResourceGrabber.main(ResourceGrabber.java:96) All downloads are finished, exiting program...
Not that this is much better…

Read full topic
item.source: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!

item.title: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:20, topic:403921”]It doesn’t start at all (I waited like 10 minutes, and it starts in less than 30 seconds for other torrent programs).

I have a rather complex network setup, and have pretty strict firewall settings (hardware and software), but I didn’t see any events in any of the logs… Anyway, it has the ‘standard’ ports open, and no other torrent programs have an issue, nor do other applications that use a P2P protocol (once I actually allow them, if they’re not already allowed).[/quote]

I always use a random port, and only operate with encryption (don’t connect to non-encrypted clients at all), I also make a request to forward the port via UPnP and NAT-PMP, would that make a difference?

[quote=“tL, post:21, topic:403921”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=500979.msg3666359#msg3666359 date=1310651208]
That is x86 right? (not ppc? I support ppc too) Also what version of the JVM are you running and what vendor? (still apple?)
[/quote]

Yep, x86_64. Lion doesn’t support PPC, and neither did Snow Leopard (the last release), and I don’t have any PPC machines :P. Also, on the subject of the JVM in Mac OS X Lion: http://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/02/27/no_java_in_mac_os_x_lion/[/quote]

Odd move, so it’s still currently Java 1.6?

Glad to know my i386 executable (compiled on linux), runs on the latest amd64 OSX though, excellent!

Read full topic
item.source: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!

item.title: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Moparisthebest:

That is x86 right? (not ppc? I support ppc too) Also what version of the JVM are you running and what vendor? (still apple?)

Yep, x86_64. Lion doesn’t support PPC, and neither did Snow Leopard (the last release), and I don’t have any PPC machines :P. Also, on the subject of the JVM in Mac OS X Lion: http://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/02/27/no_java_in_mac_os_x_lion/

Read full topic
item.source: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!

item.title: Calling all Mac/Windows/BSD/Linux users, test AGAIN please!
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:19, topic:403921”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=500979.msg3666095#msg3666095 date=1310627622]

Doesn’t seem to work on 64 bit Mint (an Ubuntu variant). I tried a few different argument combinations (along with the example), and none seemed to actually start downloading anything.

Also, I didn’t even try to run it as a superuser.

Hmm, I develop on 64-bit Ubuntu, so I know it works there, it certainly doesn’t need run as super-user (unless you don’t have read/write access to save_dir), and when you run it it should pop up a Swing window telling you the progress and such.

The window pops up, but it literally does nothing… It sits at zero percent, doesn’t transfer any data, and stays in the ‘dl metadata’ state.

Also, I’d hope that I have read/write access to /tmp and my desktop…

BTW I’m using a 64 bit JVM.
[/quote]

Oh ok, so no actual errors, just let it sit for awhile and see if it downloads the metadata and starts the download, I use the 64-bit JVM as well. Are you behind any odd firewall setups?

Seems to work fine on Mac OS X (10.7, Lion)!

Thanks, that’s one I flat out can’t test myself, so I appreciate it and am glad it works.

edit:
That is x86 right? (not ppc? I support ppc too) Also what version of the JVM are you running and what vendor? (still apple?)[/quote]
It doesn’t start at all (I waited like 10 minutes, and it starts in less than 30 seconds for other torrent programs).

I have a rather complex network setup, and have pretty strict firewall settings (hardware and software), but I didn’t see any events in any of the logs… Anyway, it has the ‘standard’ ports open, and no other torrent programs have an issue, nor do other applications that use a P2P protocol (once I actually allow them, if they’re not already allowed).

Read full topic
